column1: Kāneʻohe is a census-designated place (CDP) included in the City and County of Honolulu and located in Hawaiʻi state District of Koʻolaupoko on the island of Oʻahu. In the Hawaiian language
column2: kāne ʻohe means "bamboo man". According to an ancient Hawaiian story a local woman compared her husband's cruelty to the sharp edge of cutting bamboo; thus the place was named Kāneʻohe or "Bamboo man". The population was 34
column3: 597 at the 2010 census. Kāneʻohe is the largest of several communities along Kāneʻohe Bay and one of the two largest residential communities on the windward side of Oʻahu (the other is Kailua). The commercial center of the town is spread mostly along Kamehameha Highway.

column2: Kāneʻohe was important as an agricultural area
column3: owing to an abundance of rainfall. Today
column4: Kāneʻohe is mostly a residential community
column5: with very little agriculture in evidence.  The only commercial crop of any consequence in the area is banana.

column1: Features of note are Hoʻomaluhia Botanical Garden and the new Hawaiʻi National Veterans Cemetery. Access to Kāneʻohe Bay is mainly from the public pier and boat ramp located at nearby Heʻeia Kea. Access to Coconut Island (restricted) is from the state pier off Lilipuna Road. Marine Corps Base Hawaii lies across the south end of Kāneʻohe Bay from the central part of Kāneʻohe
column2: although the town stretches along Kāneʻohe Bay Drive to the base perimeter.

column1: The ZIP code for Kaneohe is 96744.
There are three golf courses in Kāneʻohe: Pali Golf Course (public)
column2: Koʻolau Golf Club (privately owned but open to the public)
column3: and Bayview Golf Park (privately owned but open to the public).

column2: -157.799084). Nearby towns include Kailua to the east
column3: reached either by Kāneʻohe Bay Drive (State Rte. 630) or Kamehameha Highway (State Rte. 83)
column4: the former also providing a connection to Marine Corps Base Hawaii
column5: and the latter connecting to Interstate H-3 and (at Castle Junction) Pali Highway (State Rte. 61) to Honolulu. Likelike Highway (State Rte. 63) runs southwest over and through the Koʻolau to Honolulu. Likelike provides connections to Kahekili Highway and Heʻeia
column6: and H-3 southbound to Hālawa. The first three exits on the windward side of Interstate H-3 east (north) bound access Kāneʻohe.  Following Kamehameha Highway northward from Kāneʻohe (State Rte. 830) leads through Heʻeia to Heʻeia Kea.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the CDP has a total area of 8.5 square miles (22 km2)
column3: of which 6.6 square miles (17 km2) is land and 1.9 square miles (4.9 km2) is water.  The total area is 22.80% water
column4: consisting of a portion of Kāneʻohe Bay included in the census tract.

column1: Kaneohe has a relatively dry tropical rainforest climate.

column1: The Honolulu Police Department operates the Kaneohe Substation in Kaneohe.
The Hawaii Department of Education operates the public schools.Elementary schools in Kaneohe CDP include Heʻeia
column5: and Pūʻōhala. James B. Castle High School is in the CDP.Schools with Kaneohe postal addresses but outside of the CDP include Governor Samuel Wilder King Intermediate School in Heeia CDP
column9: Kahalu'u Elementary School in Kahalu'u CDP
column10: and Waiāhole Elementary School in Waikane.There is the Hakipuʻu Learning Center
column11: a public charter school for grades 7 through 12.The Roman Catholic Diocese of Honolulu operates St. Ann Catholic School
column13: in Heeia CDP but with a Kaneohe address.Also within the boundaries of Kaneohe CDP are these private schools: Huakailani School for Girls (K-8)
column16: and Windward Nazarene Academy.Windward Community College
column17: part of the state college system
column18: is located on the south side of central Kāneʻohe.  Hawaiʻi Pacific University operates its Windward Hawaiʻi Loa campus on Kamehameha Highway near Castle Junction.
